awd_titl_txt: Statistical Inference for High-Dimensional Time Series
awd_abstract_narration:
Due to the rapid development of information technologies and their applications in many scientific fields, high dimensional time series (HDTS) are routinely collected nowadays. The methods and theory developed for the inference of low and fixed dimensional time series may not be applicable when the dimension is comparable to or exceeds time series length, and there is an urgent need to develop new statistical methods that can accommodate both high dimensionality and temporal dependence. Statistical inference for HDTS is fundamentally important and has many applications in disciplines ranging from climate science to medical imaging and finance, among others.

This project aims to develop innovative theory and methodologies to address several important inference problems in the analysis of HDTS. The research is built on the self-normalized approach, which has found great success in dealing with low dimensional problems. Its advance to the high dimensional context is challenging both methodologically and theoretically, and it requires a new methodological formulation and new theory. This project covers the inference of the mean, covariance matrix, and auto-covariance matrix  for HDTS, and the tests developed can be used to detect change points, certain structure of the covariance matrix and target dense alternative. On the theoretical front, the weak convergence of sequential U-statistic based process will be investigated and is of independent interest.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The PI has been developing the self-normalized approach to the inference of time series data since more than a decade ago.
During this funding period (2018-2022), the PI has advanced the self-normalized approach to the inference of high-dimensional time series and  developed a new testing method for the mean of high-dimensional time series and its extension to white noise testing.
In addition, major efforts have been on building a new class of change-point detection methods for high-dimensional data via U-statistics and self-normalization.  Specifically, the topics  include (1) change-point testing for both high-dimensional independent and dependent data, as well as testing-based estimation via wild binary segmentation; (2) robust change-point inference for high-dimensional data by applying
spatial sign and U-statistic; (3) adaptive testing for change-points in high-dimensional data by using Lq norm based kernel; (4)
developing a bootstrap based approach to change-point detection for high-dimensional heteroscedastic data; (5) change-point monitoring in the mean of high-dimensional data streams.


High-dimensional time series are increasingly collected in many scientific fields, including atmospheric science, environmental science, neuroscience, economics, finance and others. During the funding period, the PI has developed systematic inference methods for such time series. One of the features of the proposed self-normalization methodology is that it does not involve any tuning parameters or contain less number of tuning parameters than the existing procedures, and is relatively convenient to implement in practice.    A rigorous theory accompanies most of the
proposed methodology and it shows that the proposed methods lead to accurate inference, which is also confirmed via simulations.
On the educational front, the PI has supervised several Ph.D. students in the area of high-dimensional data analysis, change-point analysis and time series analysis.   The PI has disseminated research results by publishing them at top statistics  journals, and presenting different parts of the research at a number of conferences and department seminars.


Last Modified: 08/01/2022
Modified by: Xiaofeng Shao
